author: @diehardAMD
text: I got away from by joining the Army. But I went to college twice after. An AAS in Laser Technology and a BS in Electrical/Electronics Engineering Degree. Yeah!! And to point to the question by David Nelson @ 6:33, I agree with Harrison. And Software Engineering is not the same as Computer Science. There is an actual methodology to engineering. Thus why a Computer Scientist degree holder cannot get a MS in an engineering university. Happened with my wife. Now, she's doing an BSEE degree after having an BSCS. She sees that the two are extremes and that Computer Engineering degree meets in the middle with engineering theory.

author: @MsJavaWolf
text: I think it is a very good thing, that CS degrees focus on the theory. First of all we do need people who write all the compilers and the high speed code, who develop new protocols and so on. It's really not impossible to learn the basics of python in one week, and people in bootcamps do that. But how do you recognize, that an algorithm is fast? How do you prove, that a system meets certain security standards? Programming is not taught that much, because just programming is really not that hard. In my university, we had only one pure programming class in the first semester in Java and still after one semester everyone was able to program a 2d or even 3d game.  There are dedicated programming classes for people who are more interrested in just web programming let's say. CS should stay CS.

author: @otacon1024
text: As for college value, I guess I'm one of those people that think it's worthless :D Well, like you I think it's good for networking and meeting people, but for its primary stated purpose, education, I find it lacking in the modern internet era.  You have a bunch of courses that you have to take and will have no real good use for in life, and only a few of them will teach you what you actually want to learn. With self-learning you always learn specifically what you need to learn in order to solve the problem at hand, and therefore have the skill to later solve the same problem.  Formal education will tend to always give you the same generic set of problems that has been used for years or decades and that may or may not be useful in the real world. Testing and scores are an outdated concept. It should be thinking, experimenting, and trying something new instead of memorizing and regurgitating the same basic problem set.

author: @otacon1024
text: 3:40 Haha, that's almost exactly me. Started coding in Python a few years ago, wanted to also learn C++ for the few cases when I really needed performance and/or a lightweight binary that's not so trivial to reverse-engineer, but could never really get myself to use it for long because it feels sort of dirty and ugly compared to Python code.  Aesthetics and syntax may not be the most important factor when picking a language, but they sure as hell make it easy to use and stick with it.

author: @sneakyi
text: A CS degree won't spoon feed you a particular language. It will teach you many of the fundamentals of computing, ie. how memory allocation works in an operating system, which will give you a foundation for how programming languages work at a deeper level.   if you just want to program little applications a YouTube education is fine. If you want to build enterprise systems then the gaps in your knowledge will frustrate and hinder you.

author: @iVandal
text: Thank you for sharing. I have a similar experience. At age 19 -22, I tried different degrees in Engineering, but I did not actually know what I wanted to do.     Programming always seemed daunting to me. My first shot at programming was with C++ and microcontrollers in College at age 21, but C++ did not speak to me. I wanted to do creative stuff right away, but everything moved so slowly. I quit college 6 months later.  Then at age 25, after working part time at a grocery store for a couple of years, I signed up for a night time course in Python. A friend from childhood was a teacher in this course, and he suggested I join in.    After the first day, with a couple lines of code,  I had launched a window and played around with turtles in Turtle Graphics. I was hooked. Python spoke to me. My first thought was: "Why didn't I learn about Python 10 years ago? This is what I want to do! "  Now I study programming, and I love it (We have a formal pure programming degree here in Norway, yay! ). I even enjoy C++ now ! :P But Python had to come first to inspire me.

author: @beckettman42
text: Thanks for the video.  It is nice to know a little more about the voice behind the code.    I took electrical engineering in university and I found that in addition to being a bit out of date, they also tend to reinvent the wheel in too much detail.  I understand that it is important to understand how a transistor works but they tend to get bogged down trying to cram all those equations into our heads instead of getting us up to date like you said.  What I am liking about Python is that it evolves quickly with the modules you install and you don't have to reinvent the wheel just to do some task.  Anyways thank you. And good luck with this whole Trump......I'm going to call it......'experiment?!?' the Americans are trying out.
